In the interview, when asked about his friendship with Epstein and why he invited him to events like shooting weekends, Prince Andrew repeatedly tried to minimise the relationship. He stated that the invitation was for Ghislaine Maxwell and that Epstein was merely her "plus one." "What happened next was nothing short of remarkable, a head scratching twist. After the FBI raid, Dougan managed to slip away from police surveillance. He later emerged in Moscow, where, after seeking political asylum, he forged a new career as an IT and cyber-security consultant. After Epstein's July 2019 arrest, Dougan began posting about the existence of the alleged tapes on Facebook. In an interview, Dougan claimed that the hard drive had been taken in the 2016 FBI raid but that he had by this point realized what was on the tapes and made copies, which he said he took with him to Russia,   In September 2019, a month after Epstein's death, the Times of London reported that Dougan's alleged trove of digital and viden data had sparked the interest of MI6, the British overseas intelligence gathering service. Among Dougan's data was purportedly compro-mising material on Prince Andrew.7   As Dougan sees it, "the logical conclusion is the FBI must have seen what was on the videos and they must have seen Prince Andrew and they must have contacted MI6," he explained. "The FBI isn't going to contact MI6 unless they have a reason to share information.   Shortly after the story broke, Ron Chepesiuk, a prolific writer of true crime stories, visited Dougan in his Moscow home. Chepesiuk had reached out to Dougan a year earlier in the hope of writing a television show based on Dougan's life. For Chepesiuk, the fact that Dougan allegedly possessed these tapes added another level of Chepesiuk intrigue to the strange saga."9   During the visit, Dougan floated the idea to Chepesiuk of sam-pling some of the tapes. "I was surprised that he trusted me that much to show me the tapes," Chepesiuk said in an interview for this book. "I can see from his point of view, he wanted to have somebody verify [it]." / []

I have been a graphic designer for 39 years, I have instructed on how to perform photo editing, digitally and with an airbrush physically....  Looking at the photo... One can see his arm between his abdomen and her right lateral side. The arm length, colour, texture, value, specularity, positioning is all correct for a photograph not being altered. The hairline between shirt and tank top is correct. The wall showing between them is correctly lit et al. Her head/face has not been inserted. The red eye shared between the subjects of the photo is correct. The reflection of the girl's hair in the window is correct as well as her height. The flash interaction between the reflection and the highlight is correct. Shadow from  male projected to female on lower right lateral side is correct.  This image is unaltered. Nothing stands out.   Am 98% sure. Would need original to be 2 % more sure, or to see the emulsion / []
While it's not a direct symptom, PTSD can indirectly affect perspiration.Â Individuals with PTSD may experience sweating as a physical symptom of anxiety and stress, and the body's stress response can also lead to less perspiration in certain situations.Â However,Â PTSD doesn't cause a complete inability to sweat / []

Wow. In reflecting on this interview and scandal, especially as the Epstein Scandal re-emerges in the US, I'm struck by the fact that, following this interview, neither the press nor the public were not convinced by Prince Andrew's interview; rather, his responses had the opposite effect and intensified existing concerns. The interview was widely described as a "car crash" and a "disaster" because of several key factors:  Lack of Empathy and Responsibility Andrew's tone throughout the interview was seen as self-absorbed and lacking in empathy for Jeffrey Epstein's victims. He did not express any compassion for them and instead focused on the impact the scandal had on him, his family, and his reputation. This was a critical failure, as it alienated a public that was already concerned with the serious nature of the allegations. His use of the word "unbecoming" to describe Epstein's actions was seen as a gross understatement, further highlighting his perceived disconnect from the gravity of the crimes.  Inconsistent and Unbelievable Excuses The prince's explanations for his behavior were met with widespread disbelief and ridicule. The most notorious examples include:  1) The Pizza Express alibi: He claimed he was at a Pizza Express in Woking on the day he was alleged to have had sex with Virginia Giuffre. This highly specific and mundane alibi was seen as bizarre and unconvincing.  2) The "inability to sweat": When confronted with Giuffre's claim that he was "sweating profusely" while dancing at a London nightclub, Andrew claimed a past medical condition related to an "adrenaline overdose" from the Falklands War had left him unable to sweat. This response was widely mocked and seen as a desperate and outlandish excuse.  3) Staying at Epstein's home: He defended staying at Epstein's house in New York after Epstein had already been convicted of a sex offense by saying it was a "convenient" place to stay. This showed a startling lack of judgment and was seen as a weak justification for maintaining a relationship with a known sex offender.   A Failure to Achieve the Interview's Goal Instead of clearing his name, the interview seemed to confirm many people's suspicions. The combination of his defensive body language, his vague denials, and his specific, yet unbelievable, excuses did more to raise questions than to answer them. A public relations expert noted that Andrew "made it much worse" and "gave more oxygen to that story," ultimately leading to him stepping back from public duties just four days after the interview aired. / []

The photograph of Prince Andrew, Virginia Giuffre, and Ghislaine Maxwell, reportedly taken by Jeffrey Epstein on March 10, 2001, is supported by substantial evidence as authentic, including development records, witness testimonies, and FBI documentation. The original print is missing, likely lost during Giuffreâ€™s move to Australia, but its absence doesnâ€™t undermine the photoâ€™s credibility due to scanned copies and corroborating accounts. The image remains a critical symbol of Giuffreâ€™s allegations, though it doesnâ€™t directly prove abuse. Claims of fakery by Andrew and Maxwell appear driven by self-interest and lack concrete evidence, making the photo a likely genuine record of a controversial moment.  The Mail on Sunday reported that the back of the original photograph bears a date stamp indicating it was developed on March 13, 2001, at a Walgreens pharmacy in West Palm Beach, Florida, near Giuffreâ€™s then-home. This suggests the photo was a standard print from a disposable Kodak camera, making digital manipulation highly unlikely at the time due to technological limitations.  - **Photographerâ€™s Testimony**: Michael Thomas, a photographer who worked with Mail on Sunday reporter Sharon Churcher, viewed the original print in 2011 in Australia. Thomas took 39 copies of the image (front and back) and described claims of it being fake as â€œridiculousâ€ and â€œabsurd,â€ citing the physical nature of the print and its context within a collection of other photos from Giuffreâ€™s time with Epstein. Prince Andie, a mischievous lad with chocolate smeared across his face, stands before his mummy, Queen Eliza. "Andie, darling boy, do you happen to know who has devoured all of my chocolates?" the queen asked, her voice tinged with suspicion. With a nervous yet confident smirk, Andie replied, "Oh, mummy, I haven't the foggiest notion. It must have been one of the footmen. Perhaps it's time to dismiss them for pilfering our treats." As he spoke, chocolate wrappers spilled from his pockets, and his hands bore the telltale signs of indulgence. Queen Eliza chuckled and affectionately pinched his nose. "Oh, Andie, my dearest darling boy, you always manage to spin a tale. Such a clever rascal you are," she said, pride evident in her voice. Andie beamed with satisfaction, oblivious to his transparent deception, relishing in the belief of his own cunning. Queen Eliza's laughter lingered in the air as she left Andie to his naive schemes. / []

He's a veteran of the Falklands war, something I never even heard of until I looked up what war he fought in.  It was a war between Argentina and the U.K. for control of the Falkland islands, a set of islands (rather far) off the coast of Argentina.  907 lives were lost, most of them being from Argentina, and the U.K. won.  Today, it is a self-governed British territory, the leader of whom is a governor appointed by the British monarch. Conspiracy of Silence is a documentary which was originally listed for viewing in TV Guide Magazine, and was to be aired on the Discovery Channel on May 3, 1994. This documentary exposed a network of religious leaders and Washington politicians who flew children to Washington D.C. for sex orgies. Many children suffered the indignity of wearing nothing but their underwear and a number displayed on a piece of cardboard hanging from their necks when being auctioned off to foreigners in Las Vegas, Nevada and Toronto, Canada. At the last minute before airing, unknown congressmen threatened the TV Cable industry with restrictive legislation if this documentary was aired. Almost immediately, the rights to the documentary were purchased by unknown persons who had ordered all copies destroyed. A copy of this videotape was furnished anonymously to former Nebraska state senator and attorney John De Camp who made it available to retired FBI Agent Ted L. Gunderson. While the video quality is not top grade, this tape is a blockbuster in what is revealed by the participants involved. / ["That's nuts. Available anywhere?"]

My favorite part of the interview, and the most telling in my opinion, is when they're talking about his sweating. He says he had a medical condition that prevented him from sweating, caused by having too much adrenaline when he was shot at during war. Here he's trying to gain the respect and sympathy of the viewer by talking about his military experience. He says "....I don't sweat, or I didn't sweat at the time", then he pauses, seems to think about what he was saying, as if to make sure he's saying the right thing, mumbles something, then continues "yes, I didn't sweat at the time". He's trying to be sure he's making the correct claim, that he didn't sweat.  Anhidrosis is a very serious medical condition. If you're unable to sweat, you can die of overheating and heat stroke. So this is very much a medical condition that has to be monitored and treated. This would be easily provable by his medical provider. His attempt to disprove Virginia Giuffre's claim that he sweated profusely during their encounters, has backfired beautifully. He claimed a potentially deadly medical condition that would require medical supervision and treatment, that he's unable to prove, thereby PROVING her account of the situation. He thought he was untouchable because his mommy is the queen. Well look at how the mighty have fallen. Look at all of the situations and scandals the royal family have been a part of, and this is where the queen drew the line. If this interview occurred today, the interviewer would get to leave off the "his royal highness" bit! You know you've failed miserably when you make Charles look like the better man, and the good brother! / ["I knew a boy growing up with this condition. We in Britain, the US and Canada are considered to be equal before the law and we are presumed innocent until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt before the courts. Over the past few decades this has been. and continues to be, eroded by the media and just general gossip and distortion of facts. Personally, I will not participate in this firestorm. The newspapers and the internet are not the courts. If there is a criminal investigation on anyone no matter who then it is up to the courts to determine the guilt or innocence of a person, any person. The same applies to the sentencing of anyone found to be guilty of a charge or charges. Just as in a rape case the habits of the victim are not the issue; the issue is the conduct of the person facing the allegations before the courts. If we continue to allow these trials by allegations then none of us is safe before the tsunami of gossip, ignorance and the power of the State. / []

Emily Maitlis: Do you remember meeting [the 17-year-old Virginia Roberts] at all?  Prince Andrew: No.  Emily Maitlis: Do you know you didn't meet her, or do you just not remember?  Prince Andrew: No, I have, I don't know if I've met her. But no, I have no recollection of meeting her.  Emily Maitlis: Because she was very specific. She described the dance that you had together in Tramp's, she described meeting you, she was a 17-year-old girl meeting a senior member of the royal family.  Prince Andrew: Never happened.  Emily Maitlis: She provided a photo of the two of you together.  Prince Andrew: Yes.  Emily Maitlis: Your arm was around her waist.  Prince Andrew: Yes.  Emily Maitlis: You've seen the photo.  Prince Andrew: I've seen the photograph, yes,  Emily Maitlis: How do you explain that?  Prince Andrew: I can't, but I don't, I mean again, I have absolutely no memory of that photograph ever being taken.  Emily Maitlis: Do you recognize yourself in the photo?  Prince Andrew: Oh, yeah, it's pretty difficult not to recognize yourself.  Emily Maitlis: Your friends suggested that the photo is fake.  Prince Andrew: I think it's, from the investigations that we've done, you can't prove whether or not that photograph is faked or not, because it is a photograph of a photograph of a photograph, so it's very difficult to be able to prove it. But I don't remember that photograph ever being taken.  Emily Maitlis: But it's possible that it was you with your arm around her waist?  Prince Andrew: That's me, but whether that's my hand or whether that's the position, I...[shakes head]...I have simply no recollection of a photograph ever being taken. When I first saw this interview I got caught up with all the mass media / social media hype that he was evasive, improbable and basically self incriminating.  Iâ€™m not a great fan of Andrew, but looking at it now with unbiased eyes, I actually believe him. If you look at his responses compared with those you would expect from most people, he does seem to circumspect, hesitant and less than emphatic with his answers, and offers his explanations in a way that would make his lawyer cringe. But when you consider his background it starts to make more sense; he comes from a background which instils a code of honour, and etiquette that is alien to most of us, and I think the impression of reticence and restraint are more indicative of how he communicates in general, ie being careful to choose the right words and maintain a high level of civility to all. His biggest mistake was to go and visit Epstein in person after his conviction, and stay at his house; Andrew is not a complete idiot, if he was heâ€™d never have cut it as a Naval officer, so itâ€™s hard to understand why he felt the need to do that especially if he and Epstein were never close friends anyway, and on,y saw each other a couple of times a year. Itâ€™s  not a smoking gun, and could be construed as an exaggerated sense of propriety although at worst it could also have been a mission of damage limitation (the sort of conversation youâ€™d want to have in person outdoors in the park with nobody listening in.) That is the only real red flag I can see, but even that could have been to keep a lid on something more minor that might be used to expose him to false accusations.  A man of his high profile would have to be a complete idiot to take the risk of doing what he is accused of, not once but three times, even if he were so inclined. Not impossible, but highly improbable. When it comes to the actual accusations made against him, there is nothing implausible or disprovable about anything he said; even if the inability to sweat  sounded rather peculiar that doesnâ€™t make it false. On the flip side, there is zero solid evidence to back up the accusations against him, other than a photo of a photo of a photo which could very easily have been edited. Also, if there was any doubt that the accuser might at least be partly motivated by financial gain, the recent revelation of her 500,000 USD out of court settlement with Epstein should at least provide a clue. The following except from an article on the sweating phenomenon Andrew claims affected him suggests to me that unless Andrew can produce a physician who can vouch for such a diagnosis or (or a physicianâ€™s medical report or notes to provide documentation), Andrewâ€™s claim is implausible and probably fabricated. (I have bolded some of the cited text for emphasis.)  â€œA complete absence of sweating is called anhidrosis. It can occur in particular areas of the body or be global â€“ where more than 80% of the body has no ability to sweat. The causes are usually damage or pathology of the nervous system, or they may be inherited, such as in the case of Sjogrens Syndrome. Some individuals suffer from hypohidrosis which is a reduction in sweating and can be indicative of dehydration.â€  â€œRegarding Prince Andrewâ€™s claim, *an excess or continual exposure to adrenaline is not widely recognised as causing a lack of sweating in humans.* However, there is some data in horses that has suggested that exposure to extreme temperatures may result in damage to the type of sweat glands that respond to adrenaline.â€  â€œSimilarly, the fact that the central nervous system, and parts of it that are linked to controlling the â€œfight or flightâ€ response system, can also be involved or damaged in psychological trauma, means it is impossible to rule out this possibility without more information. There are a number of reports of individuals who have developed an idiopathic (unexplained) inability to sweat during military and extreme training.â€  https://theconversation.com/anhidrosis-why-some-people-apparently-like-prince-andrew-just-cant-sweat-127280 / []
